State child support enforcement agencies can only disclose obtained financial records for the purpose of establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. There is no liability if the disclosure was made in good faith but based on an erroneous interpretation. In case of liability, the defendant must pay damages to the plaintiff. In any action brought under subsection (b), the defendant shall be liable to the plaintiff for damages equal to $1,000 for each unauthorized disclosure of a financial record or the actual damages sustained by the plaintiff. In any action brought under subsection (b), the defendant shall be liable to the plaintiff for damages equal to $1,000 for each unauthorized disclosure of a financial record or the actual damages sustained by the plaintiff, plus punitive damages for willful or grossly negligent disclosures.
